{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3740645,"name":"Bri","username":"BriFRC","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/brifrc/{size}/131024_2.png","created_at":"2025-09-16T18:27:50.235Z","cooked":"

For my senior project I’m working on an autonomous robotic sailboat. Our sailboat uses a rigid self trimming wingsail. One of the potential things we’ve been discussing is adding a dampener to the mast, and another potential thing we’re looking at is the ability to essentially ‘brake’ the sail in one place when necessary.

I’m looking into potentially using a Falcon 500 for this purpose, as the robotics department already has some laying around, with an algorithm to apply some amount of force in the opposite direction depending on wind speed. We could also engage brake mode if we wanted to keep the mast stationary for certain maneuvers. And as a bonus, the built in encoder would be able to add positional feedback to the mast which is something we want to add anyways. That said, I have some conceptual questions I would appreciate if someone could help guide me through, or direct me to resources about.

The big thing is power: My main inspiration for this system is how regenerative braking works in EVs. Where it essentially ‘backdrives’ the motor in order to slow down the vehicle. Doing this also generates power and sends it back to the battery. If I’m trying to resist the natural motion of the sail, would it be consuming power to fight against it, or capturing it in the vein of regenerative braking? If it’s capturing it, where would that power go? Stay in the motor? Back to the battery? If it’s generating it, does anyone have any suggestions for good resources to calculate how much energy it would use over time?

I’m working on analyzing the forces involved with the sail at different wind speeds, as well as the level of dampening we might want. I have the JVN calculator which is always a great resource, but I also will not say no to more resources. If the Falcon is a bad fit, I am also totally open to other suggestions for motors that would work! Though at this point it’s less about the specific motor and more about shoring up my conceptual understanding of the system and if it’s even viable.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2025-09-16T18:27:50.235Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":185,"reads":269,"readers_count":268,"score":1003.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":506346,"topic_slug":"using-a-falcon-500-as-a-dampener-for-an-autonomous-sailboat","display_username":"Bri","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":31589,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Dream Big"},"post_url":"/t/using-a-falcon-500-as-a-dampener-for-an-autonomous-sailboat/506346/1","custom_user_title":"Dream Big","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3740669,"name":"Skye Leake","username":"Skyehawk","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skyehawk/{size}/179363_2.png","created_at":"2025-09-16T18:50:06.190Z","cooked":"

Can you help with a sense of scale here? Are we talking a 6foot model boat? 12 foot sunfish with a wing, 18 foot catamaran, C22, something bigger? Are you basically making a saildrone?

Are you aiming sailing in light winds, heavy stuff?

You are not going to have any regeneration if you are just stalling the motor to hold position.

Frankly speaking, if you have a saildrone you are likely better balancing your wing around the center of effort so the overall forces are lower from the get go and you don’t have to worry about efficiency losses through various energy conversations.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2025-09-16T18:52:45.325Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":242,"readers_count":241,"score":68.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":506346,"topic_slug":"using-a-falcon-500-as-a-dampener-for-an-autonomous-sailboat","display_username":"Skye Leake","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.saildrone.com/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Saildrone: Maritime Defense and Oceanographic Survey Solutions","clicks":8}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":19235,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Pretengineer"},"post_url":"/t/using-a-falcon-500-as-a-dampener-for-an-autonomous-sailboat/506346/2","custom_user_title":"Pretengineer","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3740670,"name":"s-neff","username":"s-neff","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/s-neff/{size}/9062_2.png","created_at":"2025-09-16T18:50:30.707Z","cooked":"

@daltzsmith got any ideas?

BriFRC:

If I’m trying to resist the natural motion of the sail, would it be consuming power to fight against it, or capturing it in the vein of regenerative braking? If it’s capturing it, where would that power go? Stay in the motor? Back to the battery? If it’s generating it, does anyone have any suggestions for good resources to calculate how much energy it would use over time?

In the case of the TalonFX, freespinning or brake modes: I expect it’s getting dumped as heat. EDIT: it’ll regen! Cool! (See below from b-hall)

In the case of reactive Regen Braking you’ll generate back-emf and push energy back into the battery.
In the case of fighting a setpoint, it’ll stall, pull a bunch of current, and dissipate a bunch of heat.

Negligible amounts, KE is small, 1/2 I (omega) ^2

BriFRC:

We could also engage brake mode if we wanted to keep the mast stationary for certain maneuvers

Depending on the scale of the vessel, brake mode is extremely unlikely to halt motion of the mast. Active position control is more likely what you’d need to implement, if you’re trying to fight the self-trimming wingsail.

TL;DR - don’t expect regenerative braking, it’ll damp fine in brakemode, but the scale of damping is unlikely to be as significant as you’re hoping. Solve for torque & KE of your sail…

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2025-09-16T19:47:12.182Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":234,"readers_count":233,"score":156.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":506346,"topic_slug":"using-a-falcon-500-as-a-dampener-for-an-autonomous-sailboat","display_username":"s-neff","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":3,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":28019,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/using-a-falcon-500-as-a-dampener-for-an-autonomous-sailboat/506346/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3740674,"name":"s-neff","username":"s-neff","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/s-neff/{size}/9062_2.png","created_at":"2025-09-16T19:03:02.883Z","cooked":"
s-neff:

@daltzsmith got any ideas?

…..part of my post got eaten by Discource? There’s supposed to be a explanation of BLDC regen braking above this….

”Regen braking” involves taking back-EMF generated by spinning the motorshaft from the external load, and feeding the back-EMF to the battery.
That’s stupid easy on a brushed DC motor onto a DC bus, because spinning the shaft makes DC happen mechanically. Connect the H-bridges in the controller and now the battery gets fed by the DC.

BLDC is most commonly a 3multi-pole system at the motor, so spinning the motor shaft won’t automatically give you DC - it needs to be rectified by the controller timing against the encoder position. This doesn’t matter in FRC, so I doubt CTRE has a firmware that does this. I tagged Daltz to see if he knew about non-FRC firmwares that might implement something like that. EDIT: CTRE does this, neat!

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2025-09-16T19:48:41.626Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":205,"readers_count":204,"score":101.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":506346,"topic_slug":"using-a-falcon-500-as-a-dampener-for-an-autonomous-sailboat","display_username":"s-neff","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":28019,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/using-a-falcon-500-as-a-dampener-for-an-autonomous-sailboat/506346/4","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3740675,"name":"Bri","username":"BriFRC","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/brifrc/{size}/131024_2.png","created_at":"2025-09-16T19:05:45.541Z","cooked":"

We’re competing in this competition. https://www.sailbot.org/

This is last year’s team’s paper. Student Work | SailBot 2024-25 | ID: kd17cz447 | Digital WPI

They were looking at a liquid dampener, but I’m not sure if that’s the best solution, because we would want variable dampening based on wind speed, which is why a motor is potentially appealing. Though I’m potentially concerned about power draw, as the endurance challenge has us out there for 8 hours without coming back to dock. The sail also managed to get stuck into irons a few times during last years competition, so being able to nudge the sail out of that configuration could be good. But we’re still very much in the early phases of this, so I’m trying to balance a lot of factors while learning more about the bot in general.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2025-09-16T19:05:45.541Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":190,"readers_count":189,"score":58.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":506346,"topic_slug":"using-a-falcon-500-as-a-dampener-for-an-autonomous-sailboat","display_username":"Bri","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.sailbot.org/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"SailBot | International Robotic Sailing Regatta","clicks":20},{"url":"https://digital.wpi.edu/concern/student_works/kd17cz447?locale=en","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Student Work | SailBot 2024-25 | ID: kd17cz447 | Digital WPI","clicks":8}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":19235,"username":"Skyehawk","name":"Skye Leake","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skyehawk/{size}/179363_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":31589,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Dream Big"},"post_url":"/t/using-a-falcon-500-as-a-dampener-for-an-autonomous-sailboat/506346/5","custom_user_title":"Dream Big","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3740682,"name":"","username":"Alex_Y","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/82dd89/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-09-16T19:16:40.486Z","cooked":"

I would highly suggest talking to any mechatronics facility at your school. They will know more than people on CD.

BriFRC:

We could also engage brake mode if we wanted to keep the mast stationary for certain maneuvers.

Brake mode doesn’t hold the motor stationary, it just shorts the motor such that the produced back-emf opposes motion of the shaft. You will need some sort of feedback controller to prevent all movement which will consume additional power.

BriFRC:

The big thing is power: My main inspiration for this system is how regenerative braking works in EVs. Where it essentially ‘backdrives’ the motor in order to slow down the vehicle. Doing this also generates power and sends it back to the battery. If I’m trying to resist the natural motion of the sail, would it be consuming power to fight against it, or capturing it in the vein of regenerative braking? If it’s capturing it, where would that power go? Stay in the motor? Back to the battery?

If you want any behavior other than brake mode, consuming, even if we pretend the motor controller doesn’t have idle draw. But you will have some regen. The regen will cause voltage to appear across the leads, and how bad this is depends on your setupp. In some setups, the battery can cope with the regen, but in others, it will trip power supplies or damage electronics. You will likely have to look at the spec sheets of the rest of your setup to know if they can tolerate regen. If backdriving is problematic, you can use a regen clamp to dissipate the back-emf.

BriFRC:

If it’s generating it, does anyone have any suggestions for good resources to calculate how much energy it would use over time?

It depends heavily on the operating conditions and what control method and tuning you are using. If you know both of those, its easy enough to solve by creating a dynamic sim using the 1-phase model for the motor, but this feels like the type of problem where you can’t really know the operating conditions well at all.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2025-09-16T19:16:40.486Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":184,"readers_count":183,"score":71.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":506346,"topic_slug":"using-a-falcon-500-as-a-dampener-for-an-autonomous-sailboat","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50219,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/using-a-falcon-500-as-a-dampener-for-an-autonomous-sailboat/506346/6","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3740684,"name":"Skye Leake","username":"Skyehawk","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skyehawk/{size}/179363_2.png","created_at":"2025-09-16T19:16:48.891Z","cooked":"
BriFRC:

They were looking at a liquid dampener

Briefly going off on this tangent:

Can you source/make an adjustable damper? E.g. adjust spacing between plates, or the amount of overlap on a coaxial tube version, this could easily be servo driven.

You may also be able to use a small overdriven up flywheel as an “inertial damper” if the mass isn’t as much of a concern (e.g. also mounted low to act as ballast, which could also have a brake to lock the wing axis). This would have other complications though, like needing to disengage or alter the system for light winds.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2025-09-16T19:22:27.951Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":167,"readers_count":166,"score":53.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":506346,"topic_slug":"using-a-falcon-500-as-a-dampener-for-an-autonomous-sailboat","display_username":"Skye Leake","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":19235,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Pretengineer"},"post_url":"/t/using-a-falcon-500-as-a-dampener-for-an-autonomous-sailboat/506346/7","custom_user_title":"Pretengineer","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3740685,"name":"Nyx","username":"gellnick","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gellnick/{size}/172273_2.png","created_at":"2025-09-16T19:22:37.515Z","cooked":"

Mechanical dampers exist that don‘t necessarily need power input. Here’s a great video on them:

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2025-09-16T19:23:35.602Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":159,"readers_count":158,"score":46.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":506346,"topic_slug":"using-a-falcon-500-as-a-dampener-for-an-autonomous-sailboat","display_username":"Nyx","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XWWPcWy0zmY","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":29971,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Everything and nothing, all at the same time"},"post_url":"/t/using-a-falcon-500-as-a-dampener-for-an-autonomous-sailboat/506346/8","custom_user_title":"Everything and nothing, all at the same time","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3740686,"name":"Bri","username":"BriFRC","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/brifrc/{size}/131024_2.png","created_at":"2025-09-16T19:26:34.888Z","cooked":"
Skyehawk:

Can you source/make an adjustable damper? E.g. adjust spacing between plates, or the amount of overlap on a coaxial tube version, this could easily be servo driven.

That’s definitely an option if we decide to go that route. There are benefits from motor-driven, from the ability to do minor sail adjustments if needed, to the built in encoder, but if power draw is too much of a concern we will very likely look at a system like that. Right now it’s mostly exploring options and figuring out pros and cons.

Skyehawk:

You may also be able to use a small overdriven up flywheel as an “inertial damper” if the mass isn’t as much of a concern (e.g. also mounted low to act as ballast, which could also have a brake to lock the wing axis). This would have other complications though, like needing to disengage or alter the system for light winds.

I’m not entirely certain what you mean when you say small overdriven up flywheel. Can you elaborate? And we did remove our ballast system 2 years ago, so if it’s mounted low enough that could be an option. Lots of things to think about.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2025-09-16T19:26:34.888Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":153,"readers_count":152,"score":35.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":506346,"topic_slug":"using-a-falcon-500-as-a-dampener-for-an-autonomous-sailboat","display_username":"Bri","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":31589,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Dream Big"},"post_url":"/t/using-a-falcon-500-as-a-dampener-for-an-autonomous-sailboat/506346/9","custom_user_title":"Dream Big","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3740687,"name":"Benjamin Hall","username":"bhall-ctre","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bhall-ctre/{size}/198180_2.png","created_at":"2025-09-16T19:26:42.750Z","cooked":"

The Talon FX does perform regenerative braking (particularly when enabled), which is restricted by your stator current limit. However, you’re only going to see substantial supply current regenerated when braking at a high velocity—a higher back emf corresponds to a higher duty cycle to honor the stator current limit, and supply current is stator current times duty cycle. That happens frequently in FRC (every time you brake your swerve drive), but it may not in this scenario.

Additionally, regen braking damps motion, decreasing velocity, but it cannot hold position. That requires motor output that consumes power rather than regenerating it.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2025-09-16T19:26:42.750Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":142,"readers_count":141,"score":78.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":506346,"topic_slug":"using-a-falcon-500-as-a-dampener-for-an-autonomous-sailboat","display_username":"Benjamin Hall","primary_group_name":"CTRE","flair_name":"CTRE","flair_url":"/uploads/default/original/3X/1/b/1bd2b430e1bb6427d1c6504ff6abcd31de851a6d.png","flair_bg_color":"","flair_color":"","flair_group_id":57,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":28019,"username":"s-neff","name":"s-neff","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/s-neff/{size}/9062_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":48146,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Software Engineering Intern at CTR Electronics"},"post_url":"/t/using-a-falcon-500-as-a-dampener-for-an-autonomous-sailboat/506346/10","custom_user_title":"Software Engineering Intern at CTR Electronics","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3740689,"name":"Bri","username":"BriFRC","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/brifrc/{size}/131024_2.png","created_at":"2025-09-16T19:30:07.242Z","cooked":"
Alex_Y:

I’m definitely planning on asking my advisors at the next meeting, but wanted to at least get a better understanding of what questions to ask them, and figured people on CD may have some experience with the Falcon 500 as a motor.

Alex_Y:

you can use a regen clamp to dissipate the back-emf.

What is a regen clamp? This isn’t something I’ve heard of, but considering what I know about our electrical system and current lack of BMS, having a way to address the regen if we go this route will very likely be necessary.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2025-09-16T19:30:07.242Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":141,"readers_count":140,"score":33.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":506346,"topic_slug":"using-a-falcon-500-as-a-dampener-for-an-autonomous-sailboat","display_username":"Bri","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":31589,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Dream Big"},"post_url":"/t/using-a-falcon-500-as-a-dampener-for-an-autonomous-sailboat/506346/11","custom_user_title":"Dream Big","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3740690,"name":"Bri","username":"BriFRC","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/brifrc/{size}/131024_2.png","created_at":"2025-09-16T19:33:43.419Z","cooked":"

So if I’m understanding this correctly, there will be some regen when dampening, but braking itself will consume power? Thank you. Does the motor itself have the ability to store some of that regen? Or is it dumped back into the battery/processor that’s the motor is connected to? I’m trying to figure out the types of electrical protections we would need if we decided on an application that would involve some amount of regen.

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2025-09-16T19:33:43.419Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":10,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":136,"readers_count":135,"score":37.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":506346,"topic_slug":"using-a-falcon-500-as-a-dampener-for-an-autonomous-sailboat","display_username":"Bri","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":48146,"username":"bhall-ctre","name":"Benjamin Hall","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bhall-ctre/{size}/198180_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":31589,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Dream Big"},"post_url":"/t/using-a-falcon-500-as-a-dampener-for-an-autonomous-sailboat/506346/12","custom_user_title":"Dream Big","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3740692,"name":"Skye Leake","username":"Skyehawk","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skyehawk/{size}/179363_2.png","created_at":"2025-09-16T19:35:52.443Z","cooked":"

I would do an adjustable damper over a flywheel as a the part count is lower.

However with regard to the flywheel, make one mast rotation equal 30 flywheel rotations, now you mast has more inertia (plus some small damping due to gear-train inefficiency). (E.g 118 2017 flywheel on their turret)

If you want to have a motor to also control mast (wing) rotation it will likely need to freewheel, so there is some mechanical complexity there. If you wanted to be more clever you could also do some things with a centrifical clutch to engage more flywheel mass the faster is spun, or otherwise alter the flywheel MOI (old school goveners on steam engines for example, fighting gravity) there is a ton you could do.

However the mechanical complexity balloons quickly vs an adjustable damper that is just linear servo and two closely fitting tubes with grease.

","post_number":13,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2025-09-16T19:45:24.524Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":133,"readers_count":132,"score":61.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":506346,"topic_slug":"using-a-falcon-500-as-a-dampener-for-an-autonomous-sailboat","display_username":"Skye Leake","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":31589,"username":"BriFRC","name":"Bri","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/brifrc/{size}/131024_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":19235,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Pretengineer"},"post_url":"/t/using-a-falcon-500-as-a-dampener-for-an-autonomous-sailboat/506346/13","custom_user_title":"Pretengineer","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3740694,"name":"","username":"Alex_Y","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/82dd89/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-09-16T19:41:26.303Z","cooked":"
BriFRC:

What is a regen clamp? This isn’t something I’ve heard of, but considering what I know about our electrical system and current lack of BMS, having a way to address the regen if we go this route will very likely be necessary.

Active device that will engage a high-power resistor when back-emf is generated.

BriFRC:

Thank you. Does the motor itself have the ability to store some of that regen? Or is it dumped back into the battery/processor that’s the motor is connected to? I’m trying to figure out the types of electrical protections we would need if we decided on an application that would involve some amount of regen.

Motor controllers will have a small amount of capacitance, but a vast majority of the power is dumped into the leads and whatever they are attached to.

Additionally, how tolerant is your system to hysteresis? There are easily-adjustable linear dampers (think horizontal bandsaw), but they often have significant hysteresis due to not having a constant volume and therefore having some air in the system.

","post_number":14,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2025-09-16T19:41:26.303Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":2,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":124,"readers_count":123,"score":29.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":506346,"topic_slug":"using-a-falcon-500-as-a-dampener-for-an-autonomous-sailboat","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50219,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/using-a-falcon-500-as-a-dampener-for-an-autonomous-sailboat/506346/14","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3740697,"name":"Bri","username":"BriFRC","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/brifrc/{size}/131024_2.png","created_at":"2025-09-16T19:44:18.037Z","cooked":"
Alex_Y:

Motor controllers will have a small amount of capacitance, but a vast majority of the power is dumped into the leads and whatever they are attached to.

That makes sense. This would be plugged into an ESP32 before going back to the battery, so definitely want to look into ways to handle any sort of regen to ensure it doesn’t damage the processor.

Alex_Y:

Additionally, how tolerant is your system to hysteresis? There are easily-adjustable linear dampers (think horizontal bandsaw), but they often have significant hysteresis due to not having a constant volume and therefore having some air in the system.

I’m not sure, but that’s definitely something I can look into. I appreciate the suggestions and direction!

","post_number":15,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2025-09-16T19:44:18.037Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":14,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":117,"readers_count":116,"score":23.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":506346,"topic_slug":"using-a-falcon-500-as-a-dampener-for-an-autonomous-sailboat","display_username":"Bri","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":31589,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Dream Big"},"post_url":"/t/using-a-falcon-500-as-a-dampener-for-an-autonomous-sailboat/506346/15","custom_user_title":"Dream Big","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3740701,"name":"Benjamin Hall","username":"bhall-ctre","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bhall-ctre/{size}/198180_2.png","created_at":"2025-09-16T19:45:48.430Z","cooked":"
BriFRC:

So if I’m understanding this correctly, there will be some regen when dampening, but braking itself will consume power?

When the motor is braking towards 0 velocity, it is regenerating power until you get to a low enough velocity, at which point supply current is practically 0 A (since stator current times 0% duty cycle results in no supply current).

However, when the motor is under load, motor braking cannot hold position; it can only reduce velocity. If you need to hold position, then you need to run position PID instead, which means that once you’re no longer decelerating from a high velocity, you are consuming power to drive to position using PID.

","post_number":16,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2025-09-16T19:47:35.577Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":12,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":117,"readers_count":116,"score":58.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":506346,"topic_slug":"using-a-falcon-500-as-a-dampener-for-an-autonomous-sailboat","display_username":"Benjamin Hall","primary_group_name":"CTRE","flair_name":"CTRE","flair_url":"/uploads/default/original/3X/1/b/1bd2b430e1bb6427d1c6504ff6abcd31de851a6d.png","flair_bg_color":"","flair_color":"","flair_group_id":57,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":48146,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Software Engineering Intern at CTR Electronics"},"post_url":"/t/using-a-falcon-500-as-a-dampener-for-an-autonomous-sailboat/506346/16","custom_user_title":"Software Engineering Intern at CTR Electronics","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3740706,"name":"Skye Leake","username":"Skyehawk","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skyehawk/{size}/179363_2.png","created_at":"2025-09-16T19:52:39.551Z","cooked":"

","post_number":17,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2025-09-16T19:52:39.551Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":13,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":114,"readers_count":113,"score":22.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":506346,"topic_slug":"using-a-falcon-500-as-a-dampener-for-an-autonomous-sailboat","display_username":"Skye Leake","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":19235,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Pretengineer"},"post_url":"/t/using-a-falcon-500-as-a-dampener-for-an-autonomous-sailboat/506346/17","custom_user_title":"Pretengineer","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3740733,"name":"Rod","username":"Weldingrod1","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/weldingrod1/{size}/162109_2.png","created_at":"2025-09-16T20:25:55.126Z","cooked":"

An adjustable damping device that can fully lock is called a magnetic particle clutch or brake. You have finely powdered magnetic material and parts that can move through it. No field it looks like a low loss liquid. Add some magnetic field and you get a continuously variable damping, all the way to “doesn’t turn”. This won’t give you regeneration capability, though.

If you want to pull more energy, you might gear up a brushless motor (like a NEO) and then use an active three phase rectifier/boost converter on it. You treat the motor coils kind of like the inductors in a boost converter; this will let you pull more current out than you would with simpler electronics. BUT, complicated design time needed….

en.wikipedia.org

Magnetic particle clutch

A magnetic particle clutch is a special type of electromagnetic clutch which does not use friction plates. Instead, it uses a fine powder of magnetically susceptible material (typically stainless steel) to mechanically link an otherwise free-wheeling disc attached to one shaft, to a rotor attached to the other shaft. This clutch is a form of a powder clutch. Torque is transmitted mechanically, through a metal powder filling. In the magnetically controlled version, an applied magnetic field is us...

bhall-ctre:

When the motor is braking towards 0 velocity, it is regenerating power until you get to a low enough velocity, at which point supply current is practically 0 A (since stator current times 0% duty cycle results in no supply current).

is there a way to adjust the strength of the regen? And if so, is this a constant configuration, or something that can be changed?

I found this in an old thread, but the link it’s referring to no longer exists.

Help with Falcon 500 brake mode

You can use Talon FX’s ConfigStatorCurrentLimit method to dial in how strong the brake is.
